name: cyclic N-compound production | cyclic N-compound | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7498/documentation

This dataset represents the production of cycli-N-compounds (1 kg of active ingredient). Raw materials are modelled with a stoichiometric calculation.  Energy consumption is modelled with data from a similar process. The emissions are estimated. Infrastructure is included with a default value.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of precursors (acetic anhydride, acetone, adipic acid, ammonia, benzene, bromine, butene, carbon monoxide, chlorine, dichloromethane, formic acid, hydrochloric acid, hydrogen, hydrogen fluoride, hydrogen peroxide, hydrogen sulfide,  iodine, liquefied petroleum gas, lithium, methanol, methane, o-dichlorobenzene, oxygen, 1-pentanol, phenol, phosphorus, propanal, propylene glycol, propylene oxide, silicon, sodium cyanide, sodium hydroxide, sodium hypochlorite, sodium methoxide, sodium tetrahydroborate, sulfur dioxide, toluene, water decarbonised, and "water, salt, sole") at the factory gate.

This activity ends with cycli-N-compounds  at the factory gate. The dataset includes the input materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions. The dataset doesn't include emulsives, additives etc.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2021:Manufacture of pesticides and other agrochemical products

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Triazoles are produced by reacting 1,2,4-triazole and a halo-compound.; ;Morpholines are synthesized by a dehydration of a amine diol.; ;The dataset cyclic-N-compounds was calculated from the arithmetic mean of all inputs and outputs of the production of difenoconazol, fenpropimorph, flusilazol, metconazole, penconazol, propiconazole, and tebuconazole.;;Difenoconazole  is produced in five steps from m-dichlorobenzene:;C6H4Cl2 + C2H3ClO → C8H6Cl2O + HCl;C8H6Cl2O + C6H5ClO → C14H10Cl2O2 + HCl;C14H10Cl2O2 + Br2 → C14H9Cl2BrO2 + HBr;C14H9Cl2BrO2 + C3H8O2 → C17H15Cl2BrO3 + H2O;C17H15Cl2BrO3 + C2H3N3 → C19H17Cl2N3O3 + HBr ;Precursors that are used for the difenconazole production are acetyl chloride (C2H3ClO), p-chlorophenol (C6H5ClO), hydrazine (C2H3N3), and 1,2,4-triazole (C3H8O2).;;Fenpropimorph is produced in four steps from propylene oxide:;C3H6O + NH3 → C6H15NO2;C6H15NO2 → C6H14NO + H2O;C6H14NO + CH2O2 → C7H14NO2 + H2O;C7H14NO2 + C14H20O → C20H33NO + CO2;A precursor that is used for the fenpropimorph production is 3(p-tert-butylphenyl)-2-methyl-propanal (C14H20O).;;Flusilazole is produced in three steps from silicon:;Si + 3 CH2Cl2 → C2H5Cl3Si + CHCl3;C2H5Cl3Si + 2 C6H4FLi → C14H14ClF2Si + 2 LiCl;C14H14ClF2Si + C2H2N3Na → C16H15F2N3Si + NaCl;Precursors that are used for the flusilazole production are p-fluoro-lithio benzene (C6H4FLi), hydrazine (N2H4), and 1,2,4-triazole sodium (C2H2N3Na).;;Metconazole  is produced in nine steps from adipic acid:;C6H7O4 → C5H6O + H2O + CHO2;C5H6O + NaCN + HCl → C6H7N + NaCl;C6H7N + 2 H2O → C6H8O3 + NH3;C6H8O3 + CH4O → C7H10O3 + H2O;C7H10O3 + 2 CH3Cl → C9H14O3 + 2 HCl;C9H14O3 + C7H6Cl2 → C16H19ClO3 + HCl;C16H19ClO3 + H2O → C14H17ClO + CH4O + CO2;C14H17ClO + C3H9OSI → C15H19ClO + C2H6OS + HI;C15H19ClO + C2H3N3 → C17H22ClN3O;Precursors that are used for the metconazole production are 4-chloro benzyl chloride (C7H6Cl2), hydrazine (N2H4), 1,2,4-triazole (C2H3N3), and trimethyl sulfoxonium iodide (C3H9OSI).;;Penconazole is produced in eight steps from toluene:;C7H8 + 2 Cl2 → C7H6Cl2 + 2 HCl;C7H6Cl2 + Br2 → C7H5Cl2Br + HBr;C7H5Cl2Br + NaCN → C8H5Cl2N + NaBr;C8H5Cl2N + 2 H2O → C8H6Cl2O2 + NH3;C8H6Cl2O2 + C3H7Br → C11H12Cl2O2 + HBr;2 C11H12Cl2O2 + NaBH4 + HCl + H2O → 2 C11H14Cl2O + H3BO3 + NaCl;C11H14Cl2O + CH3ClO2S → C12H16Cl2O3S + HCl;C14H16Cl2O3S + C2H3N3 → C13H15Cl2N3 + CH4SO3;Precursors that are used for the penconazole production are bromo propane (C3H7Br), mesyl chloride (CH3ClO2S), 1,2,4-triazole (C2H3N3), and hydrazine (N2H4).;;Propiconazole is produced in five steps from acetic anhydride:;C4H6O3 + HCl → C2H3ClO + C2H4O2;C2H3ClO + C6H4Cl2 → C8H6Cl2O + HCl;C8H6Cl2O + Br2 → C8H5Cl2BrO + HBr;C8H5Cl2BrO + C5H12O2 → C13H15Cl2BrO2 + H2O;C13H15Cl2BrO2 + C2H3N3 → C15H17Cl2N3O2 + HBr;Precursors that are used for the propiconazole production are hydrazine (N2H4), 1,2-pentanediol (C5H12O2), and 1,2,4-triazole (C2H3N3).;;Tebuconazole is produced in six steps from acetone:;C6H6O + H2 → C6H14O2;C6H14O2 → C6H12O + H2O;C6H12O + Cl2 → C6H11ClO + HCl;C6H11ClO + C7H7Cl → C13H17ClO + HCl;C13H17ClO + CH3ONa + C2H6S + HCl → C14H19ClO + NaCl + CH4S + CH4O;C14H19ClO + C2H3N3 → C16H22ClN3O;Precursors that are used for the tebuconazole production are p-chloro-toluene (C7H7Cl), dimethyl sulfide (C2H6S), hydrazine (N2H4), and 1,2,4-triazole (C2H3N3).;;Precursors:;;Acetyl chloride (C2H3ClO) is produced from acetic anhydride and hydrogen chloride:;C4H6O3 + HCl → C2H3ClO + C2H4O2;;Bromo propane (C3H7Br) is produced from propane and bromine (Unger 1996: 1052-1062):;C3H8 + Br2 → C3H7Br + HBr;;3(p-tert-Butylphenyl)-2-methyl-propanal (C14H20O) is produced in five steps from toluene:;C7H8 + C4H8 → C11H16;2 C11H16 + 3 O2 → 3 C11H14O2 + 2 H2O;C11H14O2 + H2 → C11H14O + H2O;C11H14O + C3H6O → C14H18O + H2O;C14H18O + H2 → C14H20O;;4-Chloro benzyl chloride (C7H6Cl2) is produced from toluene and chlorine:;C7H8 + Cl2 → C7H6Cl2 + HCl;;p-Chlorophenol (C6H5ClO) is produced by chlorination of phenol:;C6H6O + Cl2 → C6H5ClO + HCl;;p-Chloro-toluene (C7H7Cl) is produced by chlorination of toluene:;C7H8 + Cl2 → C7H7Cl + HCl;;Dimethyl sulfide (C2H6S) is produced from methanol and hydrogen sulfide:;2 CH4O + H2S → C2H6S + 2 H2O;;p-Fluoro-lithio benzene (C6H4FLi) is produced in three steps from benzene:;C6H6 + 2 Br2 → C6H4Br + 2 HBr;C6H4Br + HF → C6H4BrF + HBr;C6H4BrF + Li → C6H4FLi + HBr;;Hydrazine (C2H3N3) is produced in two steps from sodium hypochlorite:;NaOCl + NH3 → NH2Cl + NaOH;NH2Cl + NaOH + NH3 → N2H4 + NaCl + H2O;;Mesyl chloride (CH3ClO2S) is produced from methane:;CH4+ SO2 + Cl2 → CH3ClO2S + HCl;;;1,2-Pentanediol (C5H12O2) is produced in two steps from pentanol:;C5H123O → C5H10 + H2O;C5H10 + H2O2 → C5H12O2;;1,2,4-Triazole (C2H3N3) is produced in two steps from ammonia:;NH3 + CO → CH3NO;2 CH3NO + N2H4 → C2H3N3 + NH3 + 2 H2O;;1,2,4-Triazole sodium salt (C2H2N3Na) is produced in three steps from ammonia:;NH3 + CO → CH3NO;2 CH3NO + N2H4 → C2H3N3 + NH3 + 2 H2O;C2H3N3 + NaOH → C2H2N3Na + H2O;;

exchanges.description:
Cyclic N-compounds can have different modes of action as fungicides. Fenpropidin and fenpropimorph act in Δ14-reductase and Δ8→Δ7-isomerase in sterol biosynthesis (erg24, erg2); difenoconazol, flusilazol, metconazolel, penconazol, propiconazole, and tebuconazole act in C14-demethylase in sterol biosynthesis (erg11/cyp51).
EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description:
There are intermediates containing bromine and iodine in this process and this input is used as an input in the bromine and iodine production.

The concentration of bromine in water, salt, sole is 0.23% = 0.0023kg/kg. Cross-referenced: 0.25% (Ullmann's encyclopedia), 0.4% (USGS). The concentration of iodine in water, salt, sole is 0.03% = 0.0003kg/kg. Cross-referenced: 0.015% - 0.12% (Ullmann's encyclopedia).
There are intermediates containing bromine and iodine in this process and this input is used as an input in the bromine and iodine production.

The concentration of bromine in water, salt, sole is 0.23% = 0.0023kg/kg. Cross-referenced: 0.25% (Ullmann's encyclopedia), 0.4% (USGS). The concentration of iodine in water, salt, sole is 0.03% = 0.0003kg/kg. Cross-referenced: 0.015% - 0.12% (Ullmann's encyclopedia).

flow.name: Formamide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from calculation of avarage consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ kg-1), and a resulting amount of heat of 2 MJ for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that inlcudes 12% steam from external energy sources.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:

Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation, based on a production capacity of 50,000 t per year and a plant life time of 50 years, therefore an amount of 4X10-10 units per kg of produced chemical  is aded to the unit process of the respective chemical. The amount is accounted for each production step. This might be an overestimation in some multistep syntheses.

exchanges.description: Estimation, assuming that the remaining amount of unreacted input materials leave the production process with the wastewater, wich is further treated in an internal wastewater plant. exchanges.description: Estimation (24 kg cooling water per kg produced chemical per step).

flow.name: Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on the assumption that 0.2% of volatile input materials is emitted to air occurring from the purge vent, the destillation vent and fugitive emission sources. Remaining gases like CH4 or CO are oxidated to CO2. The carbon contained in the removed carbon compounds from wastewater treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air (assuming  a removal efficiency of 90%).

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from calculation of avarage consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ kg-1), and a resulting amount of electricity of 0,333 kW for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that inlcudes 38% electricity.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:

Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

For the nitrogen containing compounds within the wastewater a removal efficiency of 50% was assumed. The nitrogen emitted to air (N2) is neglected.
